Award.AwardTitle: BOOST 2015 Workshop Hosted by the Enrico Fermi Institute at the University of Chicago; Chicago, IL; August 10-14, 2015.
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide participant and infrastructure support for early career scientists and graduate students to participate in the seventh BOOST workshop that is planned to take place August 10 - 14 at the University of Chicago, Il. The main goal of this workshop is to bring together people with an interest in particle physics and the eventual discovery, possibly at the LHC, of particles whose existence is not predicted in the Standard Model (SM). This interest will focus on patterns that can be experimentally recognized in particle jets arising from decays of massive, beyond SM particles decaying to lighter systems.

In addition to the study of signatures in particle jets for boosted decays of heavy systems, other questions that lie at the forefront of our understanding of beyond SM physics will also be examined. The 2015 workshop is expected to draw participation from approximately 130 physicists divided between experimental collider physics from both theoretical end experimental aspects.

Broader Impacts: The scientific thrust is basic research that affects many areas of modern science and technology. A better understanding of the potential connections between new fundamental particles will lead to determining their impact on the early universe. The program will offer a stimulating environment for interaction between diverse groups of scientists and will contribute directly to training of young US scientists. The LHC has become, in recent times, a scientific endeavour of broad interest and familiarity to many citizens of the world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The funding provided by NSF Award 1506139, titled "BOOST 2015 Workshop Hosted by the Enrico Fermi Institute", primarily supported invitations to support young scientists to attend the 7th International Joint Theory/Experiment Workshop on Phenomenology, Reconstruction and Searches for Boosted Objects in High Energy Hadron Collisions. Not only were these young scientists able to interact with and present their work to some of the leaders in this nascent field of high energy particle theory and experiment, but it also infused this important area of research with a variety of perspectives and contributions. Lastly, because several Chicagoland institutions with close intellectual ties to the physics focus of this meeting contributed to the local organization, this funding aided in highlighting and invigorating the Chicagoland activities in the area of highly boosted objects for the Run II Large Hadron Collider (LHC).
   
     In terms of grants awarded to attendees of the workshop, the funding made available by the National Science Foundation was able to provide travel and workshop fee support for five graduate students, and the registration fee for a single postdoctoral scholar to attend the workshop. This group represented a diverse cross-section of interests, including both theory and experiment, and an effort was made to provide funding to members of underrepresented groups who applied for the travel grants for the workshop. We were successful in this regard, since 40% of the funding was devoted to members of these groups. This has an important broader impact in terms of demonstrating the need for a diverse group of perspectives and contributions to the workshop.
   
     In addition to the travel support and emphasis on attendance from underrepresented groups, we organized a public screening of the critically acclaimed film "Particle Fever" as well as a panel discussion following the screening. Due to our involvement of several local area institutions in the organization of the workshop, we were able to secure a downtown Chicago venue for this screening from Northwestern University free of charge and opened the event to the general public with no entry fee. Approximately 30-40 members of the community were attracted to the event by means of social media and "word-of-mouth." The panel discussion included two female experimental particle physics faculty members, one graduate student, one postdoctoral scholar from Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, and one visiting theory faculty member. The event was a major success, with attendees staying late into the evening to discuss the film and experiences of those involved. The broader impacts of this event alone are potentially very significant.

 

Overall, the funding from the NSF was critical to the success of the BOOST 2015 workshop.
